sen.j: 青蓮院 （しょうれんいん）は、京都市東山区粟田口（あわたぐち）三条坊町にある天台宗の寺院。
sen.e: Shorenin Temple is a Tendai sect temple located in Awadaguchi-sanjobo-cho, Higashiyama Ward, Kyoto City.
Shoren-in Temple is a Tendai sect temple located in Awataguchi-sanjobo-cho, Higashiyama Ward, Kyoto City.
Shoren-in Temple is a Tendai sect temple located in Awataguchi-sanjobo-cho, Higashiyama Ward, Kyoto City.

sen.j: 「青蓮院門跡」（－もんぜき）とも称する。
sen.e: It is also known as 'Shorenin-monzeki'.
It is also known as 'Shoren-in-monzeki.'
sen.cmt: Shoren-inに訂正。ピリオドを移動。
sen.e: It is also known as 'Shoren-in-monzeki.'

sen.j: 山号はなし。
sen.e: However, it does not have an honorific mountain prefix.
However, it does not have an honorific mountain prefix.
However, it does not have an honorific mountain prefix.

sen.j: 開基（創立者）は伝教大師最澄とされる。
sen.e: The temple was founded by head priest Saicho (posthumous awarded the title Dengyo Daishi).
The temple was founded by head priest Saicho (posthumous awarded the title Dengyo Daishi).
The temple was founded by head priest Saicho (posthumous awarded the title Dengyo Daishi).

sen.j: 本尊は熾盛光仏頂(しじょうこうにょらい)である。
sen.e: The temple's principal image Shijoko Nyorai.
sen.cmt: ・principal image: 英辞郎 on the WEB
sen.e: The temple's principal image is Shijoko Nyorai.
The temple's principal image is Shijoko Nyorai.

sen.j: 青蓮院は、三千院（梶井門跡）、妙法院とともに、天台宗の三門跡寺院とされている。
sen.e: Shoren-in Temple is one of the three Monzeki temples of Tendai sect along with Sanzen-in Temple (Kaji head temple) and Myoho-in Temple).
sen.cmt: ・Sanzenin: http://dic.yahoo.co.jp/dsearch?enc=UTF-8&p=三千院&stype=1&dtype=0・Kaji head temple: http://dic.yahoo.co.jp/・Myohoin: http://dic.yahoo.co.jp/dsearch?enc=UTF-8&p=妙法院&stype=1&dtype=0
sen.e: Shoren-in Temple is one of the three Monzeki temples of Tendai sect along with Sanzen-in Temple (Kajii-monzeki) and Myoho-in Temple.
sen.cmt: Kaji head temple→Kajii-monzeki文末の")"を削除。
sen.e: Shoren-in Temple is one of the three Monzeki temples of Tendai sect along with Sanzen-in Temple (Kajii-monzeki) and Myoho-in Temple.

sen.j: 「門跡寺院」とは皇室や摂関家の子弟が入寺する寺院のことであり、青蓮院は多くの法親王（天皇の皇子や伏見宮家などの皇族の男子で出家後に親王宣下を受けた者）が門主（住職）を務め、宮門跡寺院として高い格式を誇ってきた。
sen.e: The 'Monzeki Temples' are those that were served by members of the imperial household and Sekkan Family and, among these, Shoren-in Temple has a particularly distinguished Monzeki heritige, having been served by Hoshinno (imperial princes and sons of the Fushimi-no-miya Family who became monks and renounced the title of imperial prince) chief priests.

The 'Monzeki Temples' are those that were served by members of the Imperial Household and Sekkan Family and, among these, Shoren-in Temple has a particularly distinguished Monzeki heritage, having been served by Hoshinno (imperial princes and the sons of nobles such as the Fushimi-no-miya Family, who became monks and renounced the title of Imperial prince) chief priests.
sen.cmt: imperial→Imperial heritageに訂正。伏見宮家などの皇族の男子,部分を訂正。→the sons of nobles such as the Fushimi-no-miya Family
sen.e: The 'Monzeki Temples' are those that were served by members of the Imperial Household and Sekkan Family and, among these, Shoren-in Temple has a particularly distinguished Monzeki heritage, having been served by Hoshinno (imperial princes and the sons of nobles such as the Fushimi-no-miya family, who became monks and renounced the title of Imperial prince) chief priests.

sen.j: 江戸時代に仮御所となったことがあるため「粟田御所」の称もある。
sen.e: During the Edo period, it served as a temporary palace, which led to it becoming called 'Awata-gosho'.
During the Edo period, it served as a temporary palace, which led to it becoming called 'Awata-gosho.'
During the Edo period, it served as a temporary palace, which led to it becoming called 'Awata-gosho.'

sen.j: 日本三大一覧寺院・仏像のひとつ「青不動」のある寺としても知られる。
sen.e: The temple is also known for its painting of the Blue Acala, one of the Three Great Acalas of Japan.
The temple is also known for its painting of the Blue Acala, one of the Three Great Acalas of Japan.
The temple is also known for its painting of the Blue Acala, one of the Three Great Acalas of Japan.

sen.j: 三千院、妙法院などとともに、青蓮院も比叡山上にあった房（小寺院）がその起源とされている。
sen.e: As with many other temples such as Sanzen-in Temple and Myoho-in Temple, the origin of Shoren-in Temple lies in one of the several lodging chamber for priests built atop Mt. Hiei.
As with many other temples such as Sanzen-in Temple and Myoho-in Temple, the origin of Shoren-in Temple lies in one of the several lodging chamber for priests built atop Mt. Hiei.
As with many other temples such as Sanzen-in Temple and Myoho-in Temple, the origin of Shoren-in Temple lies in one of the several lodging chamber for priests built atop Mt. Hiei.

sen.j: 青蓮院は比叡山東塔の南谷にあった青蓮坊がその起源であり、門跡寺院となって山下に移ったのは平安時代末期の行玄大僧正の時である。
sen.e: Shoren-in Temple is dervied from 'Shorenbo' in the Minamidani area of Mt. Hiei's Higashito district but was reloacted to the bottom of the mountain when it became a monzeki temple during the time of Gyogen Daisojo at the end of the Heian period.

Shoren-in Temple is derived from 'Shorenbo' in the Minamidani area of Mt. Hiei's Higashito district but was reloacted to the bottom of the mountain when it became a monzeki temple during the time of Gyogen Daisojo at the end of the Heian period.

Shoren-in Temple is derived from Shorembo in the Minamidani area of Mt. Hiei's Higashito district but was relocated to the bottom of the mountain when it became a monzeki temple during the time of Gyogen Daisojo at the end of the Heian period.
sen.cmt: Shorenbo→Shorembo ヘボン式原文に「」のない' 'を削除スペルミスを修正

sen.j: 久安6年（1150年）、鳥羽天皇の后・美福門院は青蓮院を祈願所とした。
sen.e: In 1150,Emperor Toba's empress Bifukumonin used Shoren-in Temple as a place of prayer.
In 1150, Emperor Toba's empress Bifukumonin used Shoren-in Temple as a place of prayer.
sen.cmt: Emperorの前のスペースを調整。
sen.e: In 1150, Emperor Toba's empress Bifukumonin used Shoren-in Temple as a place of prayer.

sen.j: また、上皇の第7皇子覚快法親王が行玄の弟子として入寺し、以後、皇族や摂関家の子弟が門主を務める格式高い寺院となった。
sen.e: The emperor's 7th son Kakukai joined the temple as Gyogen's disciple, after which it went on to become a highly renowned institution served by chief priests drawn from among imperial princes and sons of the Fushimi-no-miya Family.

The ex-emperor's 7th son Imperial Prince Monk Kakukai joined the temple as Gyogen's disciple, after which it went on to become a highly renowned institution served by chief priests drawn from among imperial princes and sons of the Sekkan Family.
sen.cmt: 上皇→ex-emperorKakukai→Imperial Prince Monk Kakukai摂関家→Sekkan Family
sen.e: The retired emperor's seventh son Imperial Prince Monk Kakukai joined the temple as Gyogen's disciple, after which it went on to become a highly renowned institution served by chief priests drawn from among imperial princes and sons of the Sekkan Family.

sen.j: 山下へ移転した当初は三条白川（現在地のやや北西）にあったが、河川の氾濫を避け、鎌倉時代に高台の現在地へ移った。
sen.e: At the time of it's reloaction down the mountain, the temple was sited at Sanjo-shirakawa (slightly northwest of its current location) but was moved to its current higher spot during the Kamakura period in order to avoid the flooding river.

At the time of it's relocation down the mountain, the temple was sited at Sanjo-shirakawa (slightly northwest of its current location) but was moved to its current higher spot during the Kamakura period in order to avoid the flooding river.

At the time of it's relocation down the mountain, the temple was sited at Sanjo-shirakawa (slightly northwest of its current location) but was moved to its current higher spot during the Kamakura period in order to avoid the flooding river.

sen.j: ここにはもと十楽院という寺があり、青蓮院の南東にある花園天皇陵は「十楽院上陵」（じゅうらくいんのうえのみささぎ）と称されている。
sen.e: The location was originally the site of Juraku-in Temple and the Mausoleum of Emperor Hanazono to the southeast of Shoren-in Temple is named 'Jurakuin-ue'.
The location was originally the site of Juraku-in Temple and the Mausoleum of Emperor Hanazono to the southeast of Shoren-in Temple is named 'Jurakuin-no-ue-no-misasagi.'
sen.cmt: jurakuin-no-ue-no-misasagiに訂正。ピリオドを移動。
sen.e: The location was originally the site of Juraku-in Temple and the Mausoleum of Emperor Hanazono to the southeast of Shoren-in Temple is named 'Jurakuin-no-ue-no-misasagi.'

sen.j: 歴代門主（住職）のうち、3代の慈鎮和尚慈円は歴史書『愚管抄』の著者として著名である。
sen.e: Among the successive head priests, the 3rd priest Jien (posthumously awaded the name Jichin-osho) is renowned as the author of the historical text 'Gukansho'.
Among the successive head priests, the 3rd priest Jien (posthumously awarded the name Jichin-osho) is renowned as the author of the historical text 'Gukansho.'
Among the successive head priests, the third priest Jien (posthumously awarded the name Jichin-osho) is renowned as the author of the historical text "Gukansho."

sen.j: 慈円は関白藤原忠通の子で、歌人としても知られ、天台座主を4度務めている。
sen.e: Jien was the son of FUJIWARA no Tadamichi, chief adviser to the Emperor, was also a well known poet and served 4 terms as the head of the Tendai sect.
Jien was the son of FUJIWARA no Tadamichi, chief adviser to the Emperor, was also a well known poet and served 4 terms as the head of the Tendai sect.
Jien was the son of FUJIWARA no Tadamichi, chief adviser to the Emperor, was also a well known poet and served four terms as the head of the Tendai sect.

sen.j: また、17代門主の尊円法親王は伏見天皇の第6皇子で、名筆家として知られる。
sen.e: Prince Son'en, the seventeenth head priest of Shoren-in temple and one of the sons of Emperor Fushimi, was known as a distinguished calligrapher.
Prince Son'en, the seventeenth head priest of Shoren-in temple and one of the sons of Emperor Fushimi, was known as a distinguished calligrapher.
Prince Sonen, the seventeenth head priest of Shoren-in Temple and the sixth son of Emperor Fushimi, was known as a distinguished calligrapher.
sen.cmt: temple→Templeone of the→the sixth son 原文に合うように修正"Son'en"→"Sonen"に変更しました。

sen.j: 尊円法親王の書風は「青蓮院流」と呼ばれ、江戸時代に広く普及した和様書風「御家流」の源流である。
sen.e: The style of calligraphy developed by Son'en is known as the Shorenin method, which was widely adopted during the Edo period and is the origin of the Oieryu method.
The style of calligraphy developed by Son'en is known as the Shoren-in method, which was widely adopted during the Edo period and is the origin of Japanese style of handwriting, the Oieryu method.
sen.cmt: Shoren-inに訂正。和様書風→Japanese style of handwriting
sen.e: The style of calligraphy developed by Sonen is known as the Shoren-in method, which was widely adopted during the Edo period and is the origin of Japanese style of handwriting, the Oieryu method.

sen.j: 室町時代には後に室町幕府第6代征夷大将軍足利義教となる義円が門主を務め、また衰微期の本願寺が末寺として属し、後に本願寺の興隆に尽くした蓮如もここで得度を受けている。
sen.e: In the Muromachi period, Yoshinori ASHIKAGA, 6th Seitaishogun of the Muromachi Shoganate - later known as Gien, served as head priest and, during the temple's decline, it became a branch of Hongan-ji Temple before receiving the priest Rennyo who put great efforts into the revival of Hongan-ji Temple.

In the Muromachi period, Gien - later known as Yoshinori ASHIKAGA, 6th Seiitaishogun of the Muromachi Shogunate, served as head priest, and Hongan-ji Temple became a branch during the temple's decline, before receiving the priest Rennyo who put great efforts into the revival of Hongan-ji Temple.
sen.cmt: "後に室町幕府第6代征夷大将軍足利義教となる義円"部分の英訳の順序を訂正。Seitaishogun→SeiitaishogunShoganate→Shogunate末寺となったのは本願寺なので、英訳を訂正。
sen.e: In the Muromachi period, Gien - later known as Yoshinori ASHIKAGA, sixth Seii taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians") of the Muromachi Shogunate, served as head priest, Hongan-ji Temple became a branch during the temple's decline and Rennyo who put great efforts into the revival of Hongan-ji Temple later became a priest here.
sen.cmt: 6th→sixthbefore receiving the priestを削除し、原文の「後に本願寺の興隆に尽くした蓮如もここで得度を受けている」にあうよう修正"Seiitaishogun"→"Seii taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians")"に変更しました。

sen.j: 江戸時代の天明8年（1788年）、内裏炎上の際、青蓮院は後桜町天皇の仮御所となった。
sen.e: During the Edo period in 1788, Shoren-in Temple served as the temporary palace of Emperor Gosakuramachi at the time of the Dairi Castle Fires.
During the Edo period in 1788, Shoren-in Temple served as the temporary palace of Emperor Gosakuramachi at the time of the Dairi Castle Fires.
During the Edo period in 1788, Shoren-in Temple served as the temporary palace of Emperor Gosakuramachi at the time of the Dairi Castle Fires.

sen.j: このため、「青蓮院旧仮御所」として国の史跡に指定されている。
sen.e: It is because of this that the temple was designated a National Historic Site under the name 'Former Temporary Palace Shoren-in Temple'.
It is because of this that the temple was designated a National Historic Site under the name 'Former Temporary Palace Shoren-in Temple.'
It is because of this that the temple was designated a National Historic Site under the name 'Former Temporary Palace Shoren-in Temple.'

sen.j: 近代に入り、明治26年（1893年）の火災で大部分の建物が失われた。
sen.e: In the modern era, some of the buildings were lost to fire in 1893.
In the modern era, some of the buildings were lost to fire in 1893.
In the modern era, most part of the buildings were lost to fire in 1893.
sen.cmt: some→most part 原文に合うよう修正

sen.j: 本堂、宸殿、小御所、華頂殿（書院）、叢華殿、好文亭（茶室）などがあるが、いずれも古いものではない。
sen.e: Buildings including the Hon-do (main hall), Shin-den (Emperor's residence), Kogosho (head priest's living room), Kacho-den (drawing room), Soka-den and Kobun-tei (tea room) lie within the temple precinct but they are all relatively modern.

Buildings including the Hon-do (main hall), Shin-den (Emperor's residence), Kogosho (head priest's living room), Kacho-den (drawing room), Soka-den and Kobun-tei (tea room) lie within the temple precinct but they are all relatively modern.

Buildings including the Hon-do (main hall), Shin-den (Emperor's residence), Kogosho (head priest's living room), Kacho-den (drawing room), Soka-den and Kobun-tei (tea room) lie within the temple precinct but they are all relatively modern.

sen.j: 各建物（好文亭除く）は渡り廊下でつながれている。
sen.e: All buildings (excluding Kobun-tei) are connected via covered passageways.
All buildings (excluding Kobun-tei) are connected via covered passageways.
All buildings (excluding Kobun-tei) are connected via covered passageways.

sen.j: 庭園は室町時代の相阿弥作と伝える築山泉水庭、江戸時代の小堀遠州作と伝える霧島の庭などがある。
sen.e: The temple grounds includes a garden featuring artificial hills and springs that is said to have been created by Soami during the Muromachi period, and the Garden of Kirishima said to have been created by Enshu KOBORI during the Edo period.

The temple grounds includes a garden featuring artificial hills and springs that is said to have been created by Soami during the Muromachi period, and the Garden of Kirishima said to have been created by Enshu KOBORI during the Edo period.

The temple grounds includes a garden featuring artificial hills and springs that is said to have been created by Soami during the Muromachi period, and the Garden of Kirishima said to have been created by Enshu KOBORI during the Edo period.

sen.j: 境内西側には京都市天然記念物のクスノキの巨木（5本）がある。
sen.e: The western edge of the precinct is lined by 5 large camphor trees, which are all Kyoto Natural Monuments.
The western edge of the precinct is lined by 5 large camphor trees, which are all Kyoto Natural Monuments.
The western edge of the precinct is lined by 5 large camphor trees, which are all Kyoto Natural Monuments.

sen.j: 青蓮院では、例年春と秋に期日を区切って夜間拝観を実施し、庭園のライトアップを行っている。
sen.e: At Shoren-in Temple, special night visits are held every year in spring and autumn when the gardens are illuminated.
At Shoren-in Temple, special night visits are held every year in spring and autumn when the gardens are illuminated.
At Shoren-in Temple, special night visits are held every year in spring and autumn when the gardens are illuminated.

sen.j: 本堂 - 境内奥（南側）に西面して建つ方三間、宝形造の小堂。
sen.e: Hon-do (main hall): This small 3x3 bay Hogyo-zukuri (pyramidal style roof) hall sits facing west at the back of the precinct (souther edge).
Hon-do (main hall): This small 3x3 bay Hogyo-zukuri (pyramidal style roof) hall sits facing west at the back of the precinct (southern edge).
Hon-do (main hall): This small 3 x 3 bay Hogyo-zukuri (pyramidal style roof) hall sits facing west at the back of the precinct (southern edge).
sen.cmt: xの前後にスペース挿入

sen.j: 堂内の厨子には青蓮院の本尊である熾盛光如来の曼荼羅を安置するが、通常は公開していない（天台宗開宗1,200年を記念し、2005年9月28日より同年12月28日に公開された）。
sen.e: The minature shrine within the hall houses the statue of Shoren-in Temple's principal image - the Shijoko Nyorai Mandala, but this is not ordinarily on public view (in 2005 it was exhibited from September 28th to December 28th to commemorate the 1,200th anniversary of the founding of the Tendai sect).
sen.cmt: ・principal image: 英辞郎 on the WEB
sen.e: The miniature shrine within the hall houses the statue of Shoren-in Temple's principal image - the Shijoko Nyorai Mandala, but this is not ordinarily on public view (in 2005 it was exhibited from September 28th to December 28th to commemorate the 1,200th anniversary of the founding of the Tendai sect).

The miniature shrine within the hall houses the statue of Shoren-in Temple's principal image, the Shijoko Nyorai Mandala, but this is not ordinarily on public view (in 2005 it was exhibited from September 28 to December 28 to commemorate the 1,200th anniversary of the founding of the Tendai sect).

sen.j: 熾盛光如来とは仏頂尊の一尊で、天台宗最大の秘法といわれる熾盛光法（国家鎮護、皇室の安泰などを祈る修法）の本尊であるが、この如来を寺院の本尊とするのは珍しい。
sen.e: Shijoko Nyorai is a Butchouson who is the principal image of a method of prayer known as Sijokoho - said to be the Tendai sect's greatest secret (used when praying for the protection of the nation and the security of the Emperor), but this is the only temple in Japan dedicated to this deity.

Shijoko Nyorai is a Butchouson who is the principal image of a method of prayer known as Sijokoho - said to be the Tendai sect's greatest secret (used when praying for the protection of the nation and the security of the Emperor), but this is the only temple in Japan dedicated to this deity.

Shijoko Nyorai is a Butchouson who is the principal image of a method of prayer known as Sijokoho - said to be the Tendai sect's greatest secret (used when praying for the protection of the nation and the security of the Emperor), but this is the only temple in Japan dedicated to this deity.

sen.j: 寺伝では文禄5年（1596年）作の掛軸で、中央に種子 (密教)「ボロン」(bhruuM)で表わした熾盛光如来、周囲に八大菩薩を表わしたものという。
sen.e: Shijoko Nyorai is represented at the center of the hanging scroll by the siddham seed-syllable 'bhruuM' and surrounded by representations of the eight great bodhisattvas.

According to temple's lore, Shijoko Nyorai is represented at the center of the hanging scroll (made in 1596) by the siddham seed-syllable 'bhruuM' and surrounded by representations of the eight great bodhisattvas.

According to temple's lore, Shijoko Nyorai is represented at the center of the hanging scroll (made in 1596) by the siddham seed-syllable 'bhruuM' and surrounded by representations of the eight great bodhisattvas.

sen.j: 本堂の東裏には国宝の青不動画像の複製が安置されている。
sen.e: Within the east of the hon-do is housed reproduction of the painting of the Blue Acala, a designated National Treasure.
Within the east of the hon-do is housed reproduction of the painting of the Blue Acala, a designated National Treasure.
Within the east of the hon-do is housed reproduction of the painting of the Blue Acala, a designated National Treasure.

sen.j: 小御所 - 本堂の北側に建つ入母屋造桟瓦葺きの建物。
sen.e: Kogosho (head priest's living room): A building with a formal tile hip-and-gable roof located to the north of the hon-do (main hall).
Kogosho (head priest's living room): A building with a clay Sangawara tile hip-and-gable roof located to the north of the hon-do (main hall).
sen.cmt: 桟瓦葺き→Sangawara-buki (clay Sangawara tile roofing)
sen.e: Kogosho (head priest's living room): A building with a clay Sangawara tile hip-and-gable roof located to the north of the hon-do (main hall).

sen.j: 天皇の仮御所として使用された建物を明治26年（1893年）の焼失後に復興したものである。
sen.e: This building temporarily served as the Emperor's palace and was reconstructed after being destroyed by fire in 1893.
This building temporarily served as the Emperor's palace and was reconstructed after being destroyed by fire in 1893.
This building temporarily served as the Emperor's palace and was reconstructed after being destroyed by fire in 1893.

sen.j: 小御所東側の池を中心とした庭園は室町時代、相阿弥の作と伝え、その北方の「霧島の庭」（霧島つつじを植える）は小堀遠州の作と伝える。
sen.e: The garden centered on the pond to the east of Kogosho is said to have been created by Soami during the Muromachi period and the 'Garden of Kirishima' (where Kirishima azaleas grow) to the north is said to have been created by Enshu KOBORI.

The garden centered on the pond to the east of Kogosho is said to have been created by Soami during the Muromachi period and the 'Garden of Kirishima' (where Kirishima azaleas grow) to the north is said to have been created by Enshu KOBORI.

The garden centered on the pond to the east of Kogosho is said to have been created by Soami during the Muromachi period and the 'Garden of Kirishima' (where Kirishima azaleas grow) to the north is said to have been created by Enshu KOBORI.

sen.j: 小御所近くにある「一文字手水鉢」は豊臣秀吉の奉納と伝えている。
sen.e: The 'Ichimonji-chozubachi' (naturally straight stone basin) near the Kogosho is said to have been presented to the temple by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI.
The 'Ichimonji-chozubachi' (naturally straight stone basin) near the Kogosho is said to have been presented to the temple by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI.
The 'Ichimonji-chozubachi' (naturally straight stone basin) near the Kogosho is said to have been presented to the temple by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI.

sen.j: 宸殿 - 小御所の西側に建つ、寺内で最も大きな建物。
sen.e: Shin-den (Emperor's residence): The largest building within the temple stands to the west of the Kogosho.
Shin-den (Emperor's residence): The largest building within the temple stands to the west of the Kogosho.
Shin-den (Emperor's residence): The largest building within the temple stands to the west of the Kogosho.

sen.j: 入母屋造、桟瓦葺きで、明治26年（1893年）の焼失後の復興である。
sen.e: This sangawarabuki hip-and-gable roof building was reconstructed after being destroyed by the fire of 1893.
This sangawarabuki hip-and-gable roof building was reconstructed after being destroyed by the fire of 1893.
This sangawarabuki hip-and-gable roof building was reconstructed after being destroyed by the fire of 1893.

sen.j: 「宸」は皇帝の意で、有縁の天皇の位牌を祀る堂である。
sen.e: The word 'shin' means 'Emperor' and this hall enshrines the memorial tablets of related emperors.
The word 'shin' means 'Emperor' and this hall enshrines the memorial tablets of related emperors.
The word 'shin' means 'Emperor' and this hall enshrines the memorial tablets of related emperors.

sen.j: 障壁画浜松図（襖12面、戸襖4面、壁3面の17面）が重要文化財に指定されている。
sen.e: The 'Hama Matsu zu' (images of seashores and pine trees) partition paintings (12 opaque sliding screens, 4 wooden door covered with Fusuma paper, 17 images on 3 walls) have been designated Important Cultural Properties.

The 'Hama Matsu zu' (images of seashores and pine trees) partition paintings (12 opaque sliding screens, 4 wooden door covered with Fusuma paper, 17 images on 3 walls) have been designated Important Cultural Properties.

The Hama Matsu zu (images of seashores and pine trees) partition paintings (12 opaque sliding screens, 4 wooden door covered with Fusuma paper, 17 images on 3 walls) have been designated Important Cultural Properties.

sen.j: なお、1962年に襖のうち1枚が心ない拝観者により切り取られ行方不明となっている。
sen.e: However, one of the opaque sliding screen images is still missing after being stolen in 1962.
However, one of the opaque sliding screen images is still missing after being stolen in 1962.
However, one of the opaque sliding screen images is still missing after being stolen by a thoughtless visitor in 1962.
sen.cmt: by a thoughtless visitor の訳を補足

sen.j: 宸殿西方の四脚門（御幸門）は、明正天皇の中和門院の旧殿の門を移築したもので、明治26年の火災をまぬがれている。
sen.e: To the west of the Shin-den stands the four-legged shikyaku-mon gate (for imperial visits) which was relocated from the old palace of Emperor Meisho's Empress Dowager Chukamonin and managed to avoid the fire of 1893.
sen.cmt: ・Chukamonin: http://kotobank.jp/word/中和門院・Emperor Meisho: http://dic.yahoo.co.jp/dsearch?enc=UTF-8&p=明正天皇&stype=1&dtype=0
sen.e: To the west of the Shin-den stands the four-legged Shikyaku-mon gate (for imperial visits) which was relocated from the old palace of Empress Meisho's Chukamonin and managed to avoid the fire of 1893.
sen.cmt: Shikyaku-monに訂正。明正天皇は女帝なので、Empressに訂正。中和門院は建物。
sen.e: To the west of the Shin-den stands the four-legged Shikyaku-mon gate (for imperial visits) which was relocated from the old palace of Empress Meisho's Chukamonin and managed to avoid the fire of 1893.

sen.j: 好文亭 - 青蓮院を仮御所としていた後桜町上皇が学問所として使用した茶室。
sen.e: Kobun-tei (tea room): This tea room was used as a place of study by abdicated Emperor monk Gosakuramachi after Shoren-in Temple became a temporary palace.
Kobun-tei (tea room): This tea room was used as a place of study by abdicated Emperor monk Gosakuramachi after Shoren-in Temple became a temporary palace.
Kobun-tei (tea room): This tea room was used as a place of study by retired Emperor Gosakuramachi after Shoren-in Temple became a temporary palace.

sen.j: 1993年に放火で焼失し、2年後に復元されたものである。
sen.e: The building was destroyed by arson in 1993 and rebuilt 2 years later.
The building was destroyed by arson in 1993 and rebuilt 2 years later.
The building was destroyed by arson in 1993 and rebuilt 2 years later.

sen.j: 主室は四畳半台目の茶室で、他に四畳半3室、水屋、仏間がある。
sen.e: It consists of a main 4.5 tatami mat tea room, three 4 tatami mat rooms, Mizuya (preparation area) and a butsuma (room for Buddhist images).
sen.cmt: ・Mizuya (preparation area): 英辞郎 on the WEB
sen.e: It consists of a main 4.5 and 3/4 tatami mat tea room, three 4.5 tatami mat rooms, a mizuya (preparation area) and a butsuma (room for Buddhist images).
sen.cmt: 台目→3/4 tatami mat4→4.5 mizuya→他の部屋名が小文字なので合わせました。
sen.e: It consists of a main 4.5 and 3/4 tatami mat tea room, three 4.5 tatami mat rooms, a mizuya (preparation area) and a butsuma (room for Buddhist images).

sen.j: 植髪堂 - 境内北方、拝観入口の左方に離れて建つ。
sen.e: Uegami-do: Located in the north or the precinct to the distant left side of the visitor entrance.
Uegami-do: Located in the north or the precinct to the distant left side of the visitor entrance.
Uegami-do: Located in the north or the precinct to the distant left side of the visitor entrance.

sen.j: 3代門主慈円について得度した親鸞の剃髪が奉られているといわれる。
sen.e: Said to enshrine the hair of Shinran who was ordained by 3rd head priest Jien.
Said to enshrine the hair of Shinran who was ordained by the 3rd head priest Jien.
Said to enshrine the hair of Shinran who was ordained by the third head priest Jien.

sen.j: 1759年に建立され、1880年現在地に移転。
sen.e: The building was constructed in 1759 and relocated to its current location in 1880.
The building was constructed in 1759 and relocated to its current location in 1880.
The building was constructed in 1759 and relocated to its current location in 1880.

sen.j: ちなみに、境内の楠の巨木は親鸞の手植と伝えられている。
sen.e: the large camphor trees within the precinct are said to have been personally planted by Shinran.
The large camphor trees within the precinct are said to have been personally planted by Shinran.
The large camphor trees within the precinct are said to have been personally planted by Shinran.

sen.j: 長屋門 - 拝観入口の手前右手に建つ門で、宸殿西方の四脚門と同様、明正天皇の中和門院の旧殿の門を移築したもの。
sen.e: Nagaya-mon gate: Stands just to the front right of the visitor entrance and, as with the shikyaku-mon gate to the west of the Shin-den, was relocated from the old palace of Emperor Meisho's Empress Dowager Chukamonin.
sen.cmt: ・Chukamonin: http://kotobank.jp/word/中和門院・Emperor Meisho: http://dic.yahoo.co.jp/dsearch?enc=UTF-8&p=明正天皇&stype=1&dtype=0
sen.e: Nagaya-mon gate: Stands just to the front right of the visitor entrance and, as with the Shikyaku-mon gate to the west of the Shin-den, was relocated from the old palace of Empress Meisho's Chukamonin.
sen.cmt: Shikyaku-monに訂正。セル60同様、Empress Meisho's Chukamoninに訂正。
sen.e: Nagaya-mon gate: Stands just to the front right of the visitor entrance and, as with the Shikyaku-mon gate to the west of the Shin-den, was relocated from the old palace of Empress Meisho's Chukamonin.

sen.j: 将軍塚大日堂－寺の南東、東山の山頂に位置し、青蓮院の飛び地境内となっている。
sen.e: Shogun-zuka Dainichi-do: This detached area of the temple precinct is located southeast of the temple on the peak of Mt. Higashiyama.
Shogun-zuka Dainichi-do: This detached area of the temple precinct is located southeast of the temple on the peak of Mt. Higashiyama.
Shogun-zuka Dainichi-do: This detached area of the temple precinct is located southeast of the temple on the peak of Mt. Higashiyama.

sen.j: 桓武天皇が平城京遷都にあたり、王城鎮護のため将軍の像を埋めたところと伝え、京都市街の見晴らしがよい。
sen.e: This site offers an amazing view of the city of Kyoto and is said to be the location where a statue of a Shogun was installed to defend the Emperor's palace when Emperor Kammu relocated the capital city to Heijokyo.

This site offers an amazing view of the city of Kyoto and is said to be the location where a statue of a Shogun was installed to defend the Emperor's palace when Emperor Kammu relocated the capital city to Heijokyo.

This site offers an amazing view of the city of Kyoto and is said to be the location where a statue of a Shogun was installed to defend the Emperor's palace when Emperor Kanmu relocated the capital city to Heijokyo.

sen.j: ここにも庭園があり、春・秋には夜間拝観が実施される。
sen.e: There is also a garden within these grounds in which special night visits are held in spring and autumn.
There is also a garden within these grounds in which special night visits are held in spring and autumn.
There is also a garden within these grounds in which special night visits are held in spring and autumn.

sen.j: 不動明王ニ童子像－「青不動」と通称される平安時代後期の仏画。

sen.j: 園城寺（三井寺）の黄不動、高野山明王院の赤不動とともに三不動と言われている。
